TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed CheckState extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Specifies the state of a control, such as a check box, that can be checked, unchecked, or set to an indeterminate state.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Multiple methods in <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckedListBox>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ItemCheckEventArgs> use this enumeration.
> [!NOTE] > Use an indeterminately checked control when you do not want to set a default value.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of the CheckState enumeration.
[!code-cpp[Classic CheckedListBox Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.windows.forms.c_5_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[Classic CheckedListBox Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.c_5_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Classic CheckedListBox Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.c_5_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Forms.CheckState Checked = int32(1)
.field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Forms.CheckState Indeterminate = int32(2)

Docs.summary: The control is indeterminate. An indeterminate control generally has a shaded appearance.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Windows.Forms.CheckState Unchecked = int32(0)
